instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..

threads.title: Samsung 512GB 16+12 SSD with possible rail short, need GND pad verification
threads.message:
While I don't like my chances, for once in my life I've encountered a SSD with an actual shorted rail of sorts (about 0.2R).

It's a Samsung 512GB 16+12 SSD (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013+ type). If it was a normal PC type SSD, even at 512GB, I'd just walk away but these ones are possibly worth trying to fix, especially given it appears to be "just a short" (famous last words).

In the pictures, the green marked caps are all seemingly on the same shorted rail.

I have removed two (seeming) input decoupling caps (22uF each) in the hope one of them was going to be shorted, as one did have visual defects but alas, it was not at fault).

Attached is a picture of what I'm trying to work out ( which side is ground;  *strongly suspecting* pads closest to the connector are the GND side but I'd prefer that to be confirmed before I do anything daft )

None of the caps get warm/hot during operation, so I'm suspecting the power gets cut off before it gets anywhere. Am planning on putting perhaps 0.3~0.5V in one this rail and see if anything gets warm. Unsure what the voltage limit would be (though obviously with the short it won't get very far).

Regards,
Paul.

threads.title: Samsung 512GB 16+12 SSD with possible rail short, need GND pad verification
threads.message:
EDIT: Fresh morning, good lighting, worked out that the left-hand side of the pads in the 3rd picture are GND. Applied 0.5V to the pads @ 2A max and found the culprit as circled in the picture attached.

Replaced it with a 4u7 10V 0402 cap as a 'overall precaution', would be interesting to find out what the proper value should be
